title: 110_s1497
content: The "Energy Independence Act of 2007" aims to ensure that the majority of the United States' energy needs are met by domestic and non-fossil fuel sources by 2017 and 2037 respectively. The "National Commission on Energy Independence" is established with 15 members appointed by various government officials, including the President, Senate majority leader, Senate minority leader, Speaker of the House, and House minority leader. Two co-chairpersons are designated by the President from among the members. The National Commission on Energy Independence is established with 15 members appointed by government officials. Co-chairpersons must not be from the same political party. Members must be appointed within 90 days. Vacancies will not affect the Commission's powers and will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members serve for the life of the Commission. The Commission's purpose is to conduct a comprehensive review. The National Commission on Energy Independence, established with 15 members appointed by government officials, conducts a comprehensive review of the energy policy of the United States. The Commission reviews current energy policy, identifies problems, analyzes solutions, and provides recommendations to achieve long-term energy policy goals. The Commission is required to submit a report with recommendations by December 31 of specific calendar years. The National Commission on Energy Independence, comprised of 15 members, reviews US energy policy and submits reports to Congress and the President on progress towards energy independence. The Commission's staff, led by an Executive Director, can appoint personnel and experts as needed. If legislative action is recommended, proposed language is included in the report. The Executive Director of the National Commission on Energy Independence can hire experts and consultants as needed. Federal agencies can detail employees to assist the Commission without reimbursement, without affecting their civil service status or privileges. The National Commission on Energy Independence can request technical assistance and resources from Federal agencies to carry out its duties. The Commission has reasonable access to materials, data, and information necessary for its work. Requests for access must be made in writing by the co-chairpersons of the Commission.
